author: Oliver Pickup
title: Rugby injuries: teams dig deep to reach new heights
text: For rugby players , training sessions have become almost as competitive as the games, with coaches needing to replicate the high intensity of match day in practice. Indeed, more than a third of injuries suffered in the 2013-14 English Premiership season occurred in training, according to the England Professional Rugby Injury Surveillance Project. Full contact is necessary to make players game-ready, because in 80 minutes of action they will be expected to make between 10 and 25 tackles. When players are tired – as they usually are in training – injury becomes more likely. More shockingly, injuries in matches caused players to miss 26 days’ action on average; in 2002, when the project began, it was 16 days. They have been digging in together and suffering together and will come out a better team At any one time in the 2013-14 season, each club lost a quarter of their squad. International teams have to deal with such problems too. Before the Six Nations clash with Wales this year England were without 13 players. But defence coach Andy Farrell says “brutal” training is vital. “The desire of the squad to get through one gruelling session together was absolutely awe-inspiring from a coach’s point of view,” Farrell said while the squad endured a two-week training camp in Denver, Colorado. “They have been digging in together and suffering together and will come out a better team because of that.” • For more information on health and lifestyle, visit vitality.com
